title: 111_hr2137
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act may be cited as the Routine HIV Screening Coverage Act of 2009. Congress finds that HIV/AIDS continues to infect and kill thousands of Americans, disproportionately impacting African-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, and women. It is estimated that 1.6 million Americans have been infected with HIV, with a significant number unaware of their status. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends routine HIV screening for all patients aged 13-64, regardless of risk, to increase the proportion of people who know their HIV status. Standard health insurance plans cover HIV screening when there are clinical indications or known risk factors present. Requiring health insurance plans to cover routine HIV screening is crucial in preventing HIV/AIDS spread and ensuring infected individuals receive effective treatment. SEC. 2. COVERAGE FOR ROUTINE HIV SCREENING UNDER GROUP HEALTH PLANS, INDIVIDUAL HEALTH INSURANCE COVERAGE, AND FEHBP. This section amends the Public Health Service Act to include coverage for routine HIV screening in group health plans. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must provide coverage for routine HIV screening on terms no less favorable than other health screenings. They are prohibited from denying eligibility based on avoiding this requirement or denying coverage for screening without known risk factors or clinical indication. The curr_chunk prohibits health care providers from incentivizing individuals to accept less protection, penalizing providers for following HIV screening guidelines, providing incentives for inconsistent care, or denying coverage based solely on HIV test results. The curr_chunk discusses the rules and limitations regarding HIV screening in group health plans, including not requiring individuals to undergo screening and setting limits on cost-sharing. It also mentions the notice requirement for group health plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include requirements for HIV screening in group health plans, without preempting existing state laws on health insurance coverage. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 also address HIV screening in group health plans. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must provide coverage for routine HIV screening without discrimination or denial of eligibility based on risk factors or clinical indications. The curr_chunk prohibits health care providers from incentivizing individuals to accept less protection, penalizing providers for following HIV screening guidelines, providing incentives for inconsistent care, or denying coverage based on HIV test results. The curr_chunk discusses rules of construction related to HIV screening in group health plans, including not requiring individuals to undergo screening and limiting cost-sharing for HIV screening to be similar to other routine health screenings. Group health plans must provide written notice to participants and beneficiaries about required coverage, following regulations set by the Secretary. The notice should be included in plan literature or correspondence, sent in the next mailing, yearly informational packet, or by January 1, 2010. This section does not preempt existing State laws on health insurance. The enactment of this section pertains to health insurance coverage, specifically requiring coverage for HIV screening. It does not impact ERISA provisions for group health plans. Additionally, amendments are made to section 732(a) of the Act. The enactment of this section requires health insurance coverage for routine HIV screening. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include this coverage. Group health plans must provide coverage for routine HIV screening on terms no less favorable than other health screenings. Plans cannot deny eligibility based on avoiding this requirement, deny coverage for screening without risk factors, or offer incentives to accept less. The section prohibits providers from penalizing or limiting reimbursement for providing care in accordance with HIV screening requirements, offering incentives to provide care inconsistently, or denying eligibility based on HIV test results. The section clarifies that individuals are not required to undergo HIV screening and allows for deductibles and cost-sharing related to HIV screening, as long as they are not greater than those for other routine health screenings. Section 9814 amends the Code to include coverage for routine HIV screening. Additionally, a new section 2754 is added to the Public Health Service Act for the same purpose. In general, section 2708 provisions apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to group health plans. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended to include additional sections. Section 8902 of title 5 is amended for application under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. The amendments to section 8902 of title 5, United States Code, require compliance with section 2708 of the Public Health Service Act for group health plans and health benefit plans starting from January 1, 2010. Coordination among the Secretaries of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Treasury is mandated for administration. The memorandum of understanding mandates coordination among the Secretaries of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Treasury for regulations, rulings, and interpretations to have the same effect and enforce requirements with a coordinated strategy to avoid duplication of efforts.
